headline: Haircare Tips: Try These Homemade Remedies To Fight Frizziness This Monsoon Season
content: Frizziness is very common during the monsoon season due to the high humidity levels in the air. Moisture in the atmosphere causes hair to absorb excess water, swell up, and lose its smooth structure leading to frizz, puffiness, and lack of manageability. Additionally, rainwater can strip away natural oils from the scalp and hair, making it dry and more prone to breakage. While commercial products are available, many people find effective and safer relief from natural, homemade remedies that nourish the hair, lock in moisture, and restore shine. Below we share a list of homemade remedies to help reduce frizziness for monsoon.   Mix 2 tablespoons of coconut oil with 2 tablespoons of fresh aloe vera gel. Apply this to your hair from roots to ends and leave it on for 30–45 minutes before washing. Coconut oil deeply nourishes and aloe vera soothes the scalp while sealing moisture into hair strands, reducing frizz.  Mash 1 ripe banana and mix it with 1 tablespoon of honey. Apply the paste evenly to damp hair and leave it on for 20–30 minutes. Bananas are rich in natural oils and potassium that soften hair, while honey acts as a humectant to retain moisture.  Combine half a cup of plain yogurt with 1 tablespoon of olive oil. After shampooing, use it as a conditioner. Yogurt provides protein and olive oil hydrates dry strands, smoothing out frizz naturally.  Mix 2 tablespoons of apple cider vinegar with 1 cup of water and use it as a final rinse after shampooing. This balances the hair's pH and smooths the cuticle, reducing frizz and adding natural shine.  Beat 1 egg with 1 tablespoon of olive oil. Apply this protein-rich mixture to your hair, leave it for 20 minutes, then wash off with a mild shampoo. This helps strengthen strands and tame frizz.  Soak 2 tablespoons of fenugreek seeds overnight and grind into a paste the next morning. Apply it to your scalp and hair for 30 minutes. Fenugreek is rich in lecithin which hydrates hair and fights frizziness naturally.  Mash half an avocado and mix with 2 tablespoons of curd. Apply this creamy mixture to your hair and let it sit for 30 minutes. Avocados are rich in vitamins and fatty acids that nourish dry, frizzy hair, while curd adds softness.  Save the water used for boiling rice and let it cool. Pour into a spray bottle and use it on damp hair after a wash. Rich in amino acids, rice water helps smoothen hair texture and reduce puffiness caused by humidity.  Warm some amla oil and gently massage it into your scalp once a week. Amla strengthens hair from the roots and helps retain moisture, preventing dryness and frizz.  Try these homemade remedies to reduce frizziness in the monsoon. headline: 9 Mental Health Issues & Nutrient Deficiencies It Could Indicate
content: Mental health issues can indeed be caused or worsened by nutrient deficiencies. The brain requires a range of vitamins, minerals, and amino acids to function properly, and when these are lacking, it can disrupt mood regulation, cognitive performance, and emotional resilience. A deficiency in these key nutrients can manifest as depression, anxiety, irritability, fatigue, or even more severe psychiatric symptoms. Addressing such deficiencies through diet or supplements, under medical supervision, can often lead to significant improvement in mental health. Keep reading as we share common nutreitn deficiencies and mental health issues it can cause.   Low levels of vitamin D have been strongly linked to symptoms of depression. Vitamin D helps regulate mood and ward off inflammation in the brain. Without enough sunlight or dietary sources, individuals may experience chronic sadness, fatigue, and lack of interest in activities.  Magnesium plays a key role in regulating the body's stress-response system. When deficient, the nervous system becomes more reactive, leading to heightened feelings of anxiety, restlessness, and irritability. Magnesium also helps with sleep, which can indirectly influence anxiety levels.  Iron is vital for oxygen transport to the brain and energy production. Its deficiency, especially in women, can result in fatigue, low motivation, brain fog, and even mood swings. It may mimic symptoms of depression or burnout.  Omega-3 fatty acids are essential for brain health and neurotransmitter regulation. Low levels are associated with increased mood instability, irritability, and even bipolar symptoms. Including fatty fish, flaxseeds, or supplements can help stabilise mood.  The B-vitamins are critical for the synthesis of neurotransmitters like serotonin, dopamine, and GABA. A deficiency in B6, B9 (folate), or B12 can result in poor concentration, mental fatigue, irritability, and depressive symptoms.  Both calcium and potassium play a role in muscle and nerve function. When deficient, nerve signals may misfire, leading to symptoms like palpitations, muscle spasms, and panic attacks. Replenishing these minerals can help reduce these physical triggers.  Sleep quality is deeply affected by mineral imbalances. Zinc and magnesium are needed to maintain healthy sleep patterns and regulate melatonin production. Their deficiencies may lead to insomnia, restless sleep, or frequent nighttime waking.  Selenium is a powerful antioxidant that protects the brain from oxidative stress. A deficiency may contribute to heightened anxiety, obsessive thoughts, and even symptoms related to OCD, due to its impact on thyroid function and mental clarity.  Vitamin E helps protect brain cells from oxidative stress. Inadequate levels may accelerate cognitive decline, increase forgetfulness, and contribute to neurodegenerative conditions, especially in older adults.  Watch out for these signs and nutrient deficiencies to ensure better overall health.  Disclaimer: This content including advice provides generic information only. headline: Vision Problems In Kids: Reduce Risk By Inculcating These Daily Habits
content: Certain factors can significantly increase the risk of vision problems in children. These include excessive screen time, lack of outdoor activity, poor nutrition, uncorrected refractive errors, and genetics. However, developing healthy daily habits can help support and protect your child's vision as they grow. Encouraging regular eye care, balanced diets, screen-time breaks, and eye-friendly routines can greatly reduce the risk of long-term vision issues and strain, ensuring their eyes stay healthy and functional. Keep reading as we share a list of daily habits to add to your kid's routine to reduce risk of vision problems.  This article explores some of the common eye problems in children, their symptoms, and the importance of regular eye check-ups for maintaining good vision health. World Sight Day 2023: Optometrists and ophthalmologists properly check the vision, alignment of eyes and overall eye health of your child.  Prolonged exposure to screens like TVs, tablets, smartphones, and computers can lead to digital eye strain and even myopia (nearsightedness). Set time limits for screen usage and encourage breaks every 20 minutes using the "20-20-20 rule".  Spending at least 1-2 hours outdoors daily has been shown to reduce the risk of myopia in children. Natural light and long-distance focusing help develop healthy vision, so outdoor games, cycling, or nature walks are highly beneficial.  Ensure your child reads or does homework in well-lit environments. Poor lighting can strain the eyes and lead to headaches and fatigue. Natural daylight or bright but soft artificial lighting is best for reducing eye stress.  Teach your child to keep books or screens at least 12–16 inches away from their eyes. Holding items too close can contribute to eye strain and increase the risk of developing nearsightedness.  Simple eye exercises like blinking frequently, rolling the eyes, or shifting focus from near to far can strengthen the eye muscles and reduce fatigue especially helpful after study or screen time.  Foods rich in vitamins A, C, E, zinc, and omega-3 fatty acids (like carrots, leafy greens, sweet potatoes, eggs, nuts, and fish) help support healthy eye function and reduce the risk of vision loss.  Adequate sleep is vital for eye health. Lack of rest can cause dry, tired eyes and poor visual performance. Stick to a consistent bedtime routine to allow their eyes and brain to recharge properly.  Dry eyes can result from dehydration. Ensure your child drinks enough water throughout the day to keep their eyes moisturised and comfortable, especially in dry or air-conditioned environments.  Kids often rub their eyes with dirty hands, which can lead to infections like conjunctivitis. Encourage clean hands, discourage eye rubbing, and teach the importance of not sharing towels or eye drops.  Many vision problems are silent in the early stages. Routine eye exams can help detect and address issues like lazy eye, strabismus, or uncorrected refractive errors early, boosting both vision and academic performance.  By integrating these small but powerful habits into your child's daily life, you can foster not just better eye health but also improved concentration, learning, and confidence.
